comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: here is her sister SS New York in Liverpool. They were the first twin screw steamers, with long interesting histories. Her she is in her original fittings with 3 funnels in service with the Inman line. Launched in 1888 (City of NY) and 1889 (City of Paris),they each quickly won the Blue Ribband. Both were used by the US Navy as auxiliary cruisers in the Spanish-American War (as Harvard and Yale) Returned to service and renamed New York and Philadelphia for the American Line. In 1901-3 New York was refitted with 2 funnels and new triple expansion engines. Philadelphia (Yale) was stranded during the war and salvaged. She got her 2 funnels and was returned to service in 1901 as Philadelphia with the American Line. Both became troop transports and were renamed again in 1918 (as Plattsburg and Harrisburg) and both were broken up in 1923 in Genoa

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: In April 1914, the New York did a passenger run from Southampton to New York, arriving April 19th. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9905E7D81E39E633A... And in June 1914, the Philadelphia did a run in the other direction. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E02E7DE143EE733A...
